awd_titl_txt: Eighth Biennial Conference on Social Dilemmas: Atlanta, GA 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds a conference that will bring together a wide range of researchers who are interested in new approaches to management of common resources. The group will include political scientists, economists, sociologists, ecologists, biologists, and anthropologists who all study the ability of groups to self-organize to solve social dilemmas. The goal is to better understand how individuals behave when faced with social dilemmas and how social context and institutions support or fail to support resolution of social dilemmas. Topics include the provision and protection of public goods, international conflict, and alternatives to direct government control of resource management decisions. The conference includes junior researchers, including graduate students, post-doctoral researchers, and assistant professors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes for Award Number 1851720

The grant provided support for the Eighth Biennial Conference on Social Dilemmas. The conference was planned and hosted by the Experimental Economics Center, Andrew Young School of Policy Studies, Georgia State University. The conference was held at the Sloan School of Management, Massachusetts Institute of Technology during June 16-18, 2022.

A social dilemma is a situation in which pursuit of individual self-interest can produce group outcomes that are worse than those obtainable from collective action.  Examples include: (a) provision of public goods through voluntary contributions can lead to under provision from individuals’ free-riding on contributions by others; (b) extraction from common pool resources through individuals’ appropriations can lead to overextraction from individuals’ competing attempts to capture the resource. Currently important topics within the scope of research on social dilemmas include climate change, international conflict, provision and protection of public goods, protection of the environment and other common pool resources, and institutional support for collective action.

This eighth social dilemmas conference continued an ongoing multidisciplinary conversation ─ in progress for twenty years ─ on research on social dilemmas aimed at developing deeper insight into interaction between individual behavior, social context, and institutions that support or fail to support resolution of social dilemmas. It included theoretical and empirical research aimed at developing a better understanding of why some groups are able to solve social dilemma problems through collective action and some are not. The conference included research aimed at developing a better understanding of individual behavior in social dilemma situations and developing models of the interaction between social context and the institutions that support or fail to support resolution of social dilemmas. The research focused on developing theory that is supported by data and also on practical applications including emerging scientific and political issues concerning the commons and social dilemmas.

 

Insights from the papers presented and discussed at the conference are relevant for understanding individual and group behavior in the presence of social dilemmas and the effects of social and political institutions in improving outcomes.  Better understanding of behavior and institutions can provide foundations for improving public and private policies and practices that affect outcomes from environments characterized by social dilemmas. 

Participants included researchers from economics, political science, computer science, public policy, psychology and primate research. One undergraduate student and one graduate student received financial support and training while assisting with planning activities for the conference. Eleven graduate student mentees received financial support to participate in the conference; eight of them presented papers while three others both assisted with management of the conference and participated in all conference activities.

There were 51 participants from universities across the United States and Europe. The conference program is available at https://www.canva.com/design/DAFBcDVJHAY/jxu7E6TTtAW599X4r95h2g/view?website#4:thursday

A report on conference activities is available at https://excenweb.gsu.edu/2022/07/29/the-8thbiennial-social-dilemmas-conference/

Research papers on the conference topic will be published in a forthcoming issue of the Journal of Economic Behavior and Organization.
